Description: Write performance-critical logic in Rust commands
Do: Use Rust commands for file I/O and system operations
Don't: Do everything in JavaScript — loses Tauri's advantage
Code Bad: fs.readFileSync(path) in JS renderer

Description: Use Tauri's type-safe IPC (invoke) between frontend and Rust
Do: Call Rust commands via invoke() with typed responses
Don't: Use HTTP requests to localhost for frontend-backend communication
Code Good: const data = await invoke<UserData>('get_user', { id: userId })
Code Bad: fetch('http://localhost:3000/api/user/' + id)

Description: Keep UI logic in frontend and system logic in Rust
Do: Frontend handles rendering; Rust handles files/network/system
Don't: Mix system calls and UI rendering in same layer
Code Good: Frontend: display data. Rust: read/write/process data
Code Bad: navigator.clipboard in frontend instead of Rust clipboard API

Description: Leverage Tauri v2 plugin system for common functionality
Do: Use official plugins: fs dialog notification clipboard
Don't: Build custom Rust code for standard OS features
Code Bad: Custom Rust file dialog implementation

Description: Enable only required API permissions in capabilities
Do: Define minimal capabilities per window in tauri.conf.json
Don't: Allow all APIs — exposes unnecessary attack surface
Code Bad: capabilities: [{ permissions: ['fs:default'] }] // too broad

Description: Validate all data received from frontend in Rust commands
Do: Sanitize and validate every invoke parameter in Rust
Don't: Trust frontend data without validation — injection risk
Code Bad: let content = std::fs::read_to_string(path)? // no validation

Description: Configure Content Security Policy for the webview
Do: Set strict CSP in tauri.conf.json to prevent XSS
Don't: No CSP — webview vulnerable to script injection
Code Bad: No CSP configured — arbitrary script execution possible

Description: Never use eval() or innerHTML with user data in webview
Do: Use DOM APIs or framework templating for dynamic content
Don't: Use innerHTML with unsanitized data — XSS in desktop app
Code Good: Use framework's template system (React JSX / Vue template)
Code Bad: document.innerHTML = userProvidedHTML

Description: Use Tauri's window management for multi-window apps
Do: Create and manage windows through Rust backend
Don't: Open new browser windows — not native behavior
Code Bad: window.open('settings.html') // browser popup not native

Description: Use custom titlebar or native decorations based on platform
Do: Use decorations: false + custom titlebar for branded look
Don't: Remove decorations with no custom titlebar — no close/minimize
Code Good: Custom titlebar with drag region + min/max/close buttons
Code Bad: decorations: false with no custom controls — can't close app

Description: Support system tray for background apps
Do: Use tray plugin for apps that run in background
Don't: Close app on window close when it should keep running
Code Bad: App exits on close — user loses background functionality

Description: Use native file dialogs for open/save operations
Do: Use @tauri-apps/plugin-dialog for native file pickers
Don't: Build custom HTML file picker — not native look/feel
Code Good: const path = await open({ filters: [{ name: 'Images', extensions: ['png', 'jpg'] }] })
Code Bad: <input type='file'> for desktop file selection

Description: Read/write files through Tauri fs plugin with scope
Do: Scope fs access to specific directories only
Don't: Allow unrestricted file system access — security risk
Code Bad: fs:default with no scope restriction

Description: Use Tauri path APIs for cross-platform file paths
Do: Use appDataDir() appConfigDir() for platform-correct paths
Don't: Hardcode Windows or Unix paths
Code Bad: const configPath = 'C:\\Users\\user\\AppData\\...'

Description: Share state across commands with Tauri managed state
Do: Use app.manage() for shared application state in Rust
Don't: Use global statics — unsafe concurrent access
Code Bad: static mut STATE: Option<Data> = None; // unsafe

Description: Use Zustand/Pinia/signals for frontend-only UI state
Do: Keep UI state (theme/sidebar/tabs) in frontend store
Don't: Send every state change to Rust — unnecessary IPC overhead
Code Bad: invoke('toggle_sidebar') // round-trip for UI-only state

Description: Implement auto-updates with Tauri updater plugin
Do: Use @tauri-apps/plugin-updater for automatic updates
Don't: Skip auto-update — users stuck on old versions
Code Good: const update = await check(); if (update) { await update.downloadAndInstall() }
Code Bad: No update mechanism — users must manually download new versions

Description: Show user-friendly update notification
Do: Show update available + changelog + install/skip buttons
Don't: Silently update or block app until updated
Code Good: Banner: 'v2.1 available: New keyboard shortcuts!' [Update Now] [Later]
Code Bad: App blocked: 'Updating...' with no option to skip

Description: Send native OS notifications
Do: Use @tauri-apps/plugin-notification for system notifications
Don't: Use no notifications — user misses important events
Code Bad: alert('Download complete') in webview — not native

Description: Keep frontend bundle small for fast cold start
Do: Use Vite with tree-shaking for minimal frontend bundle
Don't: Ship heavy frameworks — slow cold start
Code Bad: 3MB React + Material UI + chart library in simple app

Description: Make Rust commands async for non-blocking operations
Do: Use async fn for file I/O and network operations in Rust
Don't: Block main thread with sync file operations
Code Bad: #[tauri::command] fn fetch_data() -> Data { blocking_call() }

Description: Create secondary windows on demand not at startup
Do: Open settings/about windows only when user requests them
Don't: Create all windows at startup — slow launch time
Code Bad: app.setup: create main + settings + about + help windows

Description: Register global and local keyboard shortcuts
Do: Use shortcut plugin for power-user keyboard shortcuts
Don't: No keyboard shortcuts — desktop app feels like a website
Code Bad: No shortcut support — user must use mouse for everything

Description: Handle file drag-and-drop from OS into the app
Do: Use drag-drop event listeners for file imports
Don't: Require file dialog for every import — friction
Code Bad: No drag-drop support — user must always click 'Open file'

Description: Use native application menu bar
Do: Create native menu with Tauri menu API — not HTML menu
Don't: Build custom HTML menu bar — doesn't feel native
Code Bad: File

Description: Support deep links for app integration
Do: Use deep-link plugin for custom URL protocol handling
Don't: No deep linking — can't integrate with other apps
Code Good: register protocol: myapp:// → handle route in app
Code Bad: No protocol handler — users can't link directly to app features

Description: Detect and follow OS dark mode preference
Do: Read system theme and apply matching CSS variables
Don't: Hardcode light theme — ignores user OS preference
Code Bad: Always light theme regardless of OS dark mode setting

Description: Persist app settings with Tauri store plugin
Do: Use @tauri-apps/plugin-store for key-value persistence
Don't: Use localStorage for important data — wiped on webview clear
Code Good: const store = await load('settings.json'); await store.set('theme', 'dark')
Code Bad: localStorage.setItem('theme', 'dark') // not persistent across clear

Description: Use SQLite via Tauri plugin for structured local data
Do: Use tauri-plugin-sql for local database operations
Don't: Use IndexedDB for complex queries — poor performance
Code Bad: IndexedDB for relational data with joins

Description: Configure builds for Windows/macOS/Linux
Do: Use Tauri's build system with platform-specific configuration
Don't: Build only for one platform — limits audience
Code Bad: Only building .exe — macOS and Linux users excluded
